questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a common collateral pathway for venous return in cases of IVC obstruction?

options.C: Superficial veins of the anterior abdominal wall

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pulmonary veins Explanation: Pulmonary veins do not serve as a collateral pathway in cases of IVC obstruction. Vertebral venous plexus (Option A): True statement, the vertebral venous plexus is a common collateral pathway for venous return in cases of IVC obstruction. Internal thoracic veins (Option B): True statement, the internal thoracic veins (also called the internal mammary veins) are another common collateral route during IVC obstruction. They connect to the subclavian veins and can provide an alternative route for venous return to the heart. Superficial veins of the anterior abdominal wall (Option C): True statement, the superficial veins of the anterior abdominal wall, particularly the paraumbilical veins, form collateral pathways through the epigastric veins. In the case of IVC obstruction, these veins become prominent and can provide venous drainage. Inferior vena cava obstruction: Collaterals develop due to obstruction of the inferior vena cava. Etiology: Thrombosis Embolism Extrinsic compression like tumor, pregnancy Pathology: Ultimately blood is connected to the superior vena cava through extensive venous collateral systems. Collateral systems: Azygosâ€“hemiazygos venous system, vertebral venous plexuses. Superficial veins of the thoracic and abdominal walls- thoraco-epigastric anastomosis. Note: Lumbar veins contribute significantly to these pathways . Lumbar veins: Thoraco-epigastric collateral: The superior epigastric vein forms anastomose with lateral thoracic vein and the inferior epigastric vein forms anastomose with internal thoracic vein. The anastomosis formed is known as thoraco-epigastric anastomosis. Lateral thoracic vein drains into the axillary vein. The axillary vein continues as the subclavian vein. The subclavian vein receives the internal thoracic vein. The subclavian vein drains into the brachiocephalic vein. Brachiocephalic vein drains into superior vena cava. Superior vena cava drains into the right atrium.

questions.question: How many Houston's valves are typically present in the human rectum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 4 Explanation: There are typically 4 Houston's valves in the human rectum. Houston's valves (or permanent folds) are semilunar (crescentic) transverse folds in the rectum. They are located against the concavities of the lateral curvatures of the rectum. They are formed by the reduplication of the mucous membrane containing submucous tissue and thickening of circular smooth muscle of the rectal wall. Houston's valves are permanent and become more prominent when the rectum is distended. According to Houston, there are four valves numbered from above downward: First valve: Located near the upper end, close to the rectosigmoid junction, projecting from the right or left wall. Second valve: About 1 inch (2.5 cm) above the third fold, projecting from the left rectal wall along the concavity of the upper lateral curvature. Third valve: The largest, most constant, and most important valve, located on the anterior and right wall of the rectum along the concavity of the middle lateral curvature, at the level of the upper end of the ampulla. Fourth valve: Located on the left wall of the rectum along the concavity of the lower lateral curvature, about 2.5 cm below the third valve. Reference: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, Vishram Singh, Volume II, 2nd Edition, Page 282

questions.question: Which of the following is not involved in the formation of the Marginal Artery of Drummond?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Inferior epigastric artery Explanation: Marginal Artery of Drummond is a circumferential anastomotic arterial channel. It extends from the ileocaecal junction to the rectosigmoid junction. It is located approximately 3 cm from the inner margin of the colon. It is formed by the anastomoses between: Colic branches of the superior mesenteric artery (i.e., ileocolic, right colic, and middle colic). Colic branches of the inferior mesenteric artery (i.e., left colic and sigmoidal). The vasa recta (small vessels) arise from the Marginal Artery of Drummond and supply the colon. Critical point of the colon: It is located at the splenic flexure. At this level, the ascending branch of the left colic artery may fail to anastomose with the left branch of the middle colic artery. However, an anastomotic channel called the " arc of Riolan " exists between: The main trunk of the middle colic artery. The ascending branch of the left colic artery. If the arc of Riolan is poorly developed, the arterial supply to the splenic flexure is compromised. As a result, the splenic flexure may undergo ischemic changes. Reference: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, Vishram Singh, Volume II, 2nd Edition, Page 158, 159

questions.question: Examine the image below showing a cross-section of the small intestine. Which part of the small intestine does this section belong to?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Jejunum Explanation: Plicae circulares are large, prominent circular folds found in the jejunum. They are designed to increase surface area for nutrient absorption. In contrast, the ileum has smaller, less prominent folds, and the duodenum has fewer plicae circulares. Plicae circulares are circular folds of the mucous membrane found in the small intestine, particularly in the jejunum. These folds are more prominent, closely set, and contribute to the thicker feel of the jejunum when compared to the ileum, which has less prominent and more sparsely arranged folds. The plicae circulares increase the surface area, are more numerous in the jejunum, where the diameter of the intestine is slightly wider. In contrast, the ileum contains many more aggregated lymph follicles (Peyer's patches) but fewer plicae circulares. Differences between the Jejunum and the Ileum: Feature Jejunum Ileum Walls Thicker and more vascular Thinner and less vascular Lumen Wider, often found empty Narrower, often found full Circular folds/plicae circulares (valves of Kerckring) Longer and closely set Smaller and sparsely set Villi More, larger, thicker, and leaf-like Fewer, shorter, thinner, and finger-like Aggregated lymph follicles (Peyer's patches) Small, circular, and few in number, found only in the distal part of the jejunum Large, oval, more in number, found throughout the ileum, maximum in the distal part Mesentery Contains less fat, becomes semitranslucent between the vasa recta, called peritoneal windows Contains more fat,

questions.question: Where is the paraduodenal recess located, and which structure is found in its fold?

options.A: To the right of the duodenum, contains the superior mesenteric artery.
options.B: To the left of the fourth part of the duodenum, contains the inferior mesenteric vein.
options.C: To the left of the fourth part of the duodenum, contains the superior mesenteric vein.
options.D: In front of the pancreas, contains the splenic vein.

questions.explanation: vein. Correct Answer: B) To the left of the fourth part of the duodenum, contains the inferior mesenteric vein. Explanation: The paraduodenal recess is an anatomical feature located to the left of the fourth part of the duodenum. It is situated behind the paraduodenal fold of the peritoneum. The key feature of this recess is that it contains the inferior mesenteric vein (IMV) in the free border of the paraduodenal fold. Duodenal Recesses: At the duodenojejunal junction, small pocket-like pouches of peritoneum, called duodenal recesses, may occur. These recesses can sometimes lead to strangulated retroperitoneal hernias. The key recesses around the duodenojejunal flexure are: Superior Duodenal Recess : Located to the left of the upper end of the fourth part of the duodenum, behind the superior duodenojejunal fold, with its orifice facing downward. Inferior Duodenal Recess : Found just below the superior recess, behind the inferior duodenojejunal fold, with its orifice facing upward. Paraduodenal Recess : The lowest recess, located to the left of the fourth part of the duodenum behind the paraduodenal fold, with its orifice facing medially. The fold contains the inferior mesenteric vein. Retroduodenal Recess : The largest, but rarely present; located behind the third and fourth parts of the duodenum, with its orifice facing downward and left.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the anatomical extent of the attached border of the following structure?

options.A: Duodenojejunal flexure to the ileocecal junction
options.B: Pylorus of the stomach to the transverse colon
options.C: Duodenojejunal flexure to the right iliac fossa

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Duodenojejunal flexure to the ileocecal junction Explanation: The given image represents the mesentery. The attached border, or the root of mesentery, is attached to an oblique line across the posterior abdominal wall, extending from the duodenojejunal flexure to the ileocecal junction. The mesentery presents two borders: Attached border (or root). Free border (or intestinal border). Root of mesentery (attached border): Extends from the duodenojejunal flexure to the ileocecal junction. Structures crossed by root of mesentery: Free border (intestinal border): Its length permits the free mobility of the loops of jejunum and ileum in the abdominal cavity. Near the intestinal border it presents fat-free oval/circular windows (translucent area) of peritoneum. The amount of fat is greater in the distal part of the mesentery. The contents of the mesentery are: Superior mesenteric artery and vein (in the root)â€”with vein being to the right of the artery. Jejunal and ileal branches of superior mesenteric artery and accompanying veins. Lymphatics (lacteals). Lymph nodes (100â€“200 in number). Autonomic nerve plexuses. Fat and connective tissues. Jejunum and ileum (enclosed in the free border).

questions.question: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic liver disease presents with increasing abdominal swelling, difficulty swallowing, and hematemesis. On examination, he has a distended abdomen, and upon palpation, his spleen is enlarged. Which anatomical feature is primarily responsible for his hematemesis?

options.B: Left gastric to esophageal vein connections
options.C: Superior to middle rectal vein connections
options.D: Splenic to inferior mesenteric vein connections

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Left gastric to esophageal vein connections. Explanation: This case is indicative of portal hypertension, a common consequence of chronic liver disease. left gastric to esophageal vein connections are primarily responsible for the hematemesis. Paraumbilical to epigastric vein connections (Option A): This refers to the formation of caput medusae, which is a characteristic sign of portal hypertension. While this is a visible finding in the abdominal wall, it is not directly responsible for hematemesis. Superior to middle rectal vein connections (Option C): This describes collateral circulation between the superior rectal vein (from the portal system) and the middle rectal vein (from the systemic circulation). While this can contribute to rectal varices, it is less likely to cause hematemesis compared to esophageal varices. Splenic to inferior mesenteric vein connection (Option D): Does not directly lead to hematemesis. Portal Hypertension : Reversal of blood flow away from the portal vein due to high pressure. Clinical Features: Splenomegaly Ascites Esophageal varices Rectal varices Caput medusae Portal-Systemic Anastomoses Site of anastomosis Veins forming portocaval anastomosis Clinical signs Lower third of the esophagus Left gastric vein â†‘â†“ Esophageal veins draining into azygos vein Esophageal varices Umbilicus Paraumbilical veins â†‘â†“ Superficial veins of anterior abdominal wall Caput medusae Mid-anal canal Superior rectal vein â†‘â†“ Middle and inferior rectal veins Hemorrhoids Reference: 1. BD Chaurasiaâ€™s Human Anatomy, Lower limb Abdomen and Pelvis, Volume 2, 8th Edition, Page 331, 332, 333 2. Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, Volume 2, 2nd Edition, Page 142

questions.question: In cases of a strangulated internal hernia into the lesser sac through the epiploic foramen, the surgical approach is often made through the greater omentum as the epiploic foramen cannot be safely widened. Which of the following structures around the epiploic foramen restricts its enlargement during surgery?

options.A: Hepatic artery, bile duct, portal vein
options.D: Superior mesenteric artery, cystic duct, portal vein

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hepatic artery, bile duct, portal vein Explanation: The epiploic foramen (of Winslow) is bordered anteriorly by the right free margin of lesser omentum which contains portal vein, hepatic artery, and common bile duct within the hepatoduodenal ligament. This makes it dangerous to enlarge the foramen during surgery. Therefore, surgeons typically access the lesser sac through the greater omentum to avoid damaging these structures. Celiac trunk and splenic artery (Option B): The celiac trunk and splenic artery are located more superiorly and posteriorly to the epiploic foramen. Portal vein, duodenum, hepatic vein (Option C): While the duodenum and hepatic vein are located near the epiploic foramen, they are not as directly involved in restricting its size during surgery. Superior mesenteric artery, cystic duct, portal vein (Option D): The superior mesenteric artery and cystic duct are located more anteriorly or inferiorly and are not directly involved in the restriction of the epiploic foramen. Epiploic foramen (of Winslow) / Omental foramen: It is a vertical slit-like opening through which the lesser sac communicates with the greater sac. Situated at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra. Boundaries: Anteriorly: Right free margin of the lesser omentum Portal vein, hepatic artery, and common bile duct are located within the hepatoduodenal ligament Posteriorly: Inferior vena cava Right suprarenal gland T12 vertebra Superiorly: Caudate process of the liver Inferiorly: First part of the duodenum

questions.question: Which of the following anatomical relationships is incorrect regarding portal venous circulation?

options.A: The portal vein is formed posterior to the neck of the pancreas
options.B: The splenic vein joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the portal vein
options.C: The portal vein ends at the porta hepatis
options.D: The portal vein is located posterior to the Inferior vena cava

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The portal vein is located posterior to the Inferior vena cava Explanation: The portal vein is always located anterior to the Inferior vena cava throughout its course from the origin to the termination. The portal vein is formed posterior to the neck of the pancreas (Option A): True statement, the portal vein is formed by the junction of the superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and the splenic vein. This junction occurs posterior to the neck of the pancreas, which is a correct anatomical description. The splenic vein joins the superior mesenteric vein to form the portal vein (Option B): True statement, the splenic vein and superior mesenteric vein join together to form the portal vein behind the neck of the pancreas, which is an accurate description of the portal venous system. The portal vein ends at the porta hepatis (Option C): True statement, the portal vein travels to the porta hepatis (the hilum of the liver), where it divides into right and left branches that supply the liver. This is the correct location for the termination of the portal vein. Portal venous circulation Formation: Formed by the union of the superior mesenteric and splenic veins behind the neck of the pancreas at the level of the second lumbar vertebra Inferior mesenteric vein drains into the splenic vein Course: It runs upwards First behind the neck of the pancreas Next, behind the first part of the duodenum Lastly, in the right free margin of the lesser omentum Termination: Ends at porta hepatis by dividing into right and left branches Branches enter the liver Branches open up into the liver sinusoids Relation Part Anteriorly Posteriorly Infraduodenal part Neck of pancreas Inferior vena cava Retroduodenal part First part of duodenum, bile duct, gastroduodenal artery Inferior vena cava Supraduodenal part Hepatic artery, bile duct (free margin of the lesser omentum). Inferior vena cava Tributaries: Left gastric Right gastric Superior pancreaticoduodenal Cystic vein in its right branch Paraumbilical veins in its left branch

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and constipation. A CT scan reveals a lesion affecting the distal third of the transverse colon and the descending colon. Which of the following arteries is most likely involved in the blood supply to this region?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Inferior mesenteric artery Explanation: The inferior mesenteric artery supplies the distal third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum. Celiac trunk (Option A): Supplies the stomach, liver, spleen, but not the colon, making it incorrect. Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) (Option B): Supplies the small intestine, ascending colon, and proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon, not the distal third or descending colon. Common hepatic artery (Option D): A branch of the celiac trunk that supplies the liver and parts of the stomach, not the colon. Main Arteries of the Abdomen The abdomen's three primary arteries- celiac trunk, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery- branch from the abdominal aorta and supply blood to abdominal organs. Celiac Trunk Origin: Twelfth thoracic vertebra Branches: Left gastric, common hepatic, splenic arteries Supplies: Foregut organs (stomach, liver, pancreas, spleen, parts of the duodenum) Superior Mesenteric Artery Origin: First lumbar vertebra Supplies: Midgut organs (jejunum, ileum, cecum, ascending colon, proximal 2/3rd of transverse colon) Inferior Mesenteric Artery Origin: Third lumbar vertebra Supplies: Hindgut organs ( distal third of transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, rectum, proximal anal canal)

questions.question: During abdominal surgery, the surgeon encounters a paired venous structure running vertically along the posterior abdominal wall continuing into the thoracic cavity, just lateral to the vertebral column as shown in the image below. What is this structure most likely?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ascending lumbar vein Explanation: The paired ascending lumbar veins run vertically along the posterior abdominal wall medial to the psoas major. Ascending lumbar veins: The paired ascending lumbar veins run medial to psoas major and connect the ipsilateral common iliac, iliolumbar, and lumbar veins. They join the subcostal vein to form the azygos vein on the right and the hemiazygos on the left. Ascending lumbar veins pass through the right and left crura of the respiratory diaphragm to continue into the thoracic cavity. Blood can flow in either direction in the ascending lumbar veins. Inferior vena cava (Option A): It runs vertically and not a paired vein. Hence, not the correct option. Hemiazygos vein (Option B): The paired ascending lumbar veins join the subcostal vein to form the azygos vein on the right and the hemiazygos on the left. Renal vein (Option D): It is a paired venous structure that courses horizontally opening into the inferior vena cava almost at right angles. Hence, not the right option.

questions.question: A surgeon must be careful with the inferior vena cava and its associated vessels during laparoscopic nephrectomy. Which of the following is true about IVC?

options.A: Left gonadal vein drains directly into IVC
options.B: Common iliac veins join to form the inferior vena cava at L3 vertebra level
options.C: Three large hepatic veins drain the liver into inferior vena cava
options.D: Right and left 5th lumbar veins drain into IVC

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Three hepatic veins drain the liver into inferior vena cava Explanation: Three large and many small hepatic veins drain directly into the anterior surface of the inferior vena cava just before it pierces the diaphragm. Left gonadal vein drains directly into IVC (Option A): False. The left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein, which then drains into the IVC, not directly into the IVC. Common iliac veins join to form the inferior vena cava at L3 vertebra level (Option B): False. The common iliac veins join to form the IVC at the L5 vertebral level, not L3. Right and left 5th lumbar veins drain into IVC (Option D): False. The lumbar veins are numbered from L1 to L4, and they drain into the IVC. The 5th lumbar segment does not have corresponding veins that drain into the IVC. Inferior vena cava: Origin: Formed by the union of the right and left common iliac veins at the level of L5 vertebra. Termination: Opens into the lower and posterior part of the right atrium. Course: It ascends along the front of the vertebral column, positioned to the right of the aorta, creates a groove on the posterior surface of the liver, and passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm at the T8 vertebral level. Tributaries of IVC Key features Right and left 3rd and 4th lumbar veins It drains the posterior, lateral, and anterior abdominal walls into IVC. Right gonadal vein Left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava. Right suprarenal vein Left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein, which drains into the inferior vena cava. Right inferior phrenic vein Left inferior phrenic vein drains into the left suprarenal, or left renal vein. Right and left renal veins Left renal vein (7.5cm) is three times longer than right renal vein (2.5cm) Hepatic veins Three large and many small veins open directly into the anterior surface of the inferior vena cava just before it pierces the diaphragm. Fig: Course and Tributaries of IVC

questions.question: Which of the following is/are NOT a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? Superior vesical Obturator Middle rectal Iliolumbar Inferior gluteal
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Only 4 Explanation: The iliolumbar artery is a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery. The others are branches of the anterior division. Internal iliac artery It is a branch of the common iliac artery. It supplies the pelvic viscera. Mnemonic: Posterior Division: S: Superior gluteal artery I: Iliolumbar artery L: Lateral sacral artery Note: Anterior division gives six branches in males and seven branches in females. The uterine artery is the 7th branch. In females inferior vesical artery is replaced by the vaginal artery. Reference: Grayâ€™s Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Page 1247, 1248, 1249, 1250

questions.question: A medical student is reviewing the anatomy of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) and its branches. Which of the following statements about the IMA is false?

options.A: The IMA arises from the abdominal aorta at the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).
options.B: The IMA supplies the proximal segments of the small intestine.
options.C: The IMA gives rise to the superior rectal artery, which supplies the rectum.
options.D: IMA provides collateral circulation if SMA is stenosed

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The IMA supplies the proximal segments of the small intestine. Explanation: IMA does not supply the proximal segments of the small intestine. The proximal small intestine is primarily supplied by branches of the celiac trunk and SMA. The IMA arises from the abdominal aorta at the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3) (Option A): This is a correct statement. The IMA typically arises from the abdominal aorta at L3, 3-4 cm above aortic bifurcation. The IMA gives rise to the superior rectal artery, which supplies the rectum (Option C): The IMA gives rise to the superior rectal artery, which supplies the rectum and proximal anal canal. IMA provides collateral circulation if SMA is stenosed (Option D): IMA provides collateral circulation if SMA is stenosed, preventing ischemia of the right side. Inferior Mesenteric Artery (IMA): Origin: Arises from the abdominal aorta at L3, 3-4 cm above aortic bifurcation. Located behind the inferior border of the horizontal part of the duodenum. Smaller than celiac trunk and superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Course and Branches of IMA Branch Course & Anastomosis Supplied Regions Left Colic Artery Ascends within left colic mesentery; forms part of the marginal artery of Drummond Distal transverse colon, descending colon Sigmoid Arteries Descend obliquely in sigmoid mesocolon; anastomose with left colic and superior rectal arteries Distal descending colon, sigmoid colon Superior Rectal Artery Crosses left common iliac vessels; descends to rectum, divides into two branches Rectum, proximal anal canal Clinical Significance Colonic Ischemia: IMA provides collateral circulation if SMA is stenosed, preventing ischemia of the right side. Colonic Surgery: IMA and marginal artery are crucial for planning resections, ensuring blood supply post-surgery. Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) Surgery: IMA identification is important to prevent colonic ischemia during AAA repairs when IMA may be temporarily occluded.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with chronic postprandial abdominal pain and weight loss. Imaging reveals compression of the third part of the duodenum between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. Which of the following best explains the patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome Explanation: This condition is caused by compression of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA, often due to weight loss leading to a loss of perivascular fat, which narrows the angle between the SMA and the aorta. Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA): Origin and Course Originates from the anterior surface of the abdominal aorta, ~1 cm below the celiac trunk at L1 level. Passes behind the splenic vein, body of the pancreas, and left renal vein, separating it from the aorta. Runs anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas and third part of the duodenum, entering the mesentery. Supplies the small intestine and parts of the large intestine. Branches Branch Supplies Inferior pancreaticoduodenal Head of pancreas, duodenum Jejunal and Ileal arteries Jejunum, ileum (via arcades and straight arteries) Ileocolic artery Ileum, cecum, appendix (gives rise to cecal & appendicular arteries) Right colic artery Ascending colon Middle colic artery Transverse colon Anatomical Variations Middle colic artery may originate from various sources (dorsal pancreatic, hepatic, inferior mesenteric). Right hepatic artery arises from the SMA in ~15% of individuals. Accessory/replaced right hepatic artery may course behind the portal vein. Clinical Significance Condition Description Surgical Importance Key for procedures like bypass or embolectomy in intestinal ischemia. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome Compression of the duodenum by the SMA due to weight loss, causing obstruction. Collateral Circulation SMA anastomoses with celiac trunk and inferior mesenteric artery for backup blood flow. Inferior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome (Option B) : This is not a recognized condition; the inferior mesenteric artery does not compress the duodenum. Mesenteric Arterial Thrombosis (Option C) : This would present with acute ischemic symptoms, not chronic postprandial pain and duodenal obstruction. Aortic Aneurysm (Option D) : This would more likely cause back pain or pulsatile abdominal mass, not duodenal compression.

questions.question: A surgical procedure is planned to remove a tumor from the head of the pancreas. Which of the following arterial arcades is primarily responsible for supplying the posterior aspect of the head of the pancreas?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Posterior pancreaticoduodenal arcade Explanation: Posterior pancreaticoduodenal arcade is formed by the anastomosis of the posterior superior and posterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries, which supply the posterior aspect of the head of the pancreas. Arterial Supply to the Head of the Pancreas The head of the pancreas is supplied by branches from the celiac trunk and superior mesenteric artery . Key arteries supplying the head of the pancreas and adjacent duodenum include: Artery Type Origin Anterior Superior Pancreaticoduodenal Branches from the gastroduodenal artery Posterior Superior Pancreaticoduodenal Branches from the gastroduodenal artery Anterior Inferior Pancreaticoduodenal Branches from the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery Posterior Inferior Pancreaticoduodenal Branches from the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery Arterial arcades encircle the head of the pancreas: Arcade Type Formed By Supplies Anterior Pancreaticoduodenal (Option A ruled out) Anastomosis of anterior superior and anterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries Anterior duodenum, head of pancreas, uncinate process Posterior Pancreaticoduodenal Anastomosis of posterior superior and posterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries Posterior head of pancreas, adjacent duodenum, distal bile duct Anterior pancreaticoduodenal arcade (Option A): Formed by anastomosis of anterior superior and anterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries Supplies the anterior part of the head of the pancreas. Kirk's arcade (Option C): Formed by a right branch of the dorsal pancreatic artery anastomosing with a branch from the gastroduodenal artery or anterior pancreaticoduodenal arcade. Supplies the anterior surface of the head and neck of the pancreas. Communicating artery (Middle Pancreaticoduodenal Arcade) (Option D): Connects anterior pancreaticoduodenal arcade and posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal artery. Supplies blood to the major duodenal papilla. Fig: The arterial supply of the pancreas Fig: Anterior and posterior pancreaticoduodenal arterial arcades, typical communicating artery

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with chronic upper abdominal pain and is diagnosed with compression of the celiac trunk by the median arcuate ligament. Which of the following arteries is not a direct branch of the celiac trunk?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Inferior mesenteric artery Explanation: Inferior mesenteric artery arises independently from the abdominal aorta and supplies the hindgut, not the foregut. Left gastric artery (Option A): This is a direct branch of the celiac trunk and supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach and the lower esophagus. Splenic artery (Option B): This is also a direct branch of the celiac trunk and supplies the spleen, parts of the stomach, and pancreas. Common hepatic artery (Option C): This is another direct branch of the celiac trunk and supplies the liver, gallbladder, duodenum, and parts of the stomach. Celiac Trunk: Origin : First major artery from the abdominal aorta, arises below the aortic hiatus at T12 level. Length: 1â€“3 cm long. Branches of the Celiac Trunk Normal Trifurcation: Left gastric artery. Common hepatic artery. Splenic artery. Anatomical Variations Separate left gastric artery origin from the abdominal aorta. Inferior phrenic arteries originating from the celiac trunk. Common origin shared with the superior mesenteric artery or its branches. Compression (Dunbar Syndrome) Compression by the median arcuate ligament can cause visceral ischemia and abdominal pain. Function Supplies blood to foregut-derived organs: Distal esophagus to the middle of the duodenum. Liver, spleen, and pancreas. Reference: Grayâ€™s Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Page 1141
